Own_Message: I like let them ask questions and provide answers for those questions while filling in related background information as I am able to. We don't shy away from difficult conversations.
DIFFERENT RESPONSES FOR SIBS: Do people really hold certain values for some of their kids and other values for their other children?

Own_Message: We celebrate diversity and confront the hard truths of systemic racism.

Something along the lines of that the differences in race, color, economic status, etc are what make make us all unique and that no one is better than the rest but that’s it’s really cool that we get to acknowledge and explore these diversities because it’s important for their history and our education in many different aspects

Everyone is different in some way. Some people are tall. Some are short. Some have dark skin. Some have light skin. Some have skin that isn't dark or light. Some people speak the language we speak. Others speak different languages and come from different places. Sometimes people are treated poorly because they don't look like you and me, or they don't sound like you or me, and they aren't from where we are from. It is important we acknowledge the struggles of people who have been treated poorly, and who have been harmed because of how they may be perceived as different. And we must acknowledge the privileges we have as white Americans, and we need to use our privilege to speak up whenever we see injustices happening for people who are not as privileged. All people deserve dignity, respect, and to pursue the same opportunities we have always had handed to us. Don't forget that. Always treat everyone with love, kindness, and respect. No matter who they are, how they look, how they talk, or where they are from.

There are all different kinds of people.  We want you to strive to understand and appreciate others, both for their differences and their similarities. Because in America there is an ugly history of white racism against blacks and other minority groups that stretches back to the very beginning, we have a responsibility to make life fair and equal.
n/a
We are all different but should be treated fairly.

God create all human beings in His image and likeness. He made some look different or be from difference places, and even have different beliefs, but we must remember that it is wrong to treat someone mean because of the color of their skin or because they look or speak differently. Each person is unique and special God loves them all equally, as we should too.
DIFFERENT RESPONSES FOR SIBS: I think the age makes a difference. Before the younger ones can be self reliant and independent, they need to learn appropriate behaviors and decision making skills so they don't hurt themselves or others. My answers may be different as they get older. I also don't know why a child couldn't be both respectful of elders but also independent. Or considerate and well-behaved.

Own_Message: Sorry, not enough time for this one.  I would focus on the importance of everyone being welcome and treated with dignity and respect; that people come from different backgrounds and life experiences and that gives us different perspectives, etc.. etc.

People come in all shapes, sizes and colors. That’s what makes everyone unique and beautiful. However, there will always be people who want to believe they are better than others and will find a reason for that like religion or skin color or gender. Sadly many people have suffered because of this such as black people in the United States. Our history of slavery is one of the darkest periods of our country. But we need to learn about it and recognize it so it never happens again.

We are all different, with different bodies, different families, different experiences and different lives.  That is what makes us great.  Because when you have a problem to solve,  you can draw on the experiences of others to get better solutions.  It's kind of like painting a rainbow, the more colors and types of colors you have, the prettier the rainbow will be.   Now, in the past, some people were treated poorly because of their skin color, or because of they have a disability, or because they have a different family.  That's silly and hurtful to do.  Because even though we're all different, we're all still human beings and we need to learn to treat all human beings with respect and kindness.  Something else I want to point out.  There are people out there that will say because someone in Black or in a wheelchair, that they must act in a specific way, or think in a specific way.  That's a stereotype and it's not true.  You should be careful of those.  Don't make assumptions about people based on their skin or ability or family life. Okay?  That's very important.  There are people who want to clump everyone together, and that's not okay.  Just because yo'ure in a wheelchair, doesn't mean you have the same life experiences as everyone else in a wheelchair.  So it's important to get to know the individual, and not make assumptions based on what makes them different.
Each person is special and deserves to be loved and treated fairly. Sometimes we agree, sometimes we disagree, and we all make mistakes, but we all deserve respect.

Someone should not be treated a particular way because of their skin, religion, language or anything else that makes them who they are.  There are some people that do this,  and it is unfair and not acceptable.  Differences are beautiful and should be celebrated. They allow us to learn and grow and have empathy. You are both black and white and should celebrate just being you!
Everyone is created in the image of G-d and everyone has a purpose to being in this world.

People are all different and we need to celebrate those differences and learn and grown from other people's prespectives.  There are some people who have been treated unfairly because of the color of their skin.  We need to learn and talk about those experiences, so we have a better presective how they feel and their point of view.

People have had very different experiences in our country, our city - even our neighborhood - because of the color of their skin, where they are from, what language they speak, and all kinds of other differences.  We can't pretend that this doesn't happen, we have to work hard to stop it from happening.  It's important that we don't let those old perceptions influence how we feel about people.  We need to also be aware of how we interact with the world and with others, and see how and when we can help others to see this too.

God has created people all over the world with many different cultures and customs and ways of living life. It’s amazing how much we can learn from each other. Not only do we celebrate our different cultures, but also our physical differences, and how creative our God is in making each person unique and beautiful. Throughout history people have made many terrible examples of how to treat one another with love and dignity, and this still is happening daily. It’s important that we recognize and notice when a person or group of people are not being treated justly and with dignity and respect. This is something we have to learn to speak up about and make sure we are improving our world and taking action when things need to be repaired.
Not everyone in our community has been treated fairly, we need to understand how they were treated and why it happened so we can do better.

You have experienced times that someone thought something about you that wasn't true, right?  Remember when Trump won the election, and someone at school told you that Papi would be deported? That person just assumed that because you are Latina, your Papi is Latinoand he must be in the U.S. illegally and that Trump would make that happen. That isn't true about Papi, right? How did it make you feel that someone made that statement based on your ethnic heritage? Was that a kind thing to say to you?  No, you deserve respect the same as everyone else at school. Do you think there are ever times that we should treat someone differently because we know they come from a different background? For example, if Liza's mom tells me that she wants to sign her up for volleyball like you, I might say, "Great!".  But if I know that Leslie's mom (mother of a friend who doesn't speak English well) wants to sign her up for sports and there are no Spanish-speaking people at the sports camp, I might offer to help Leslie's mom with registration. Did I treat the 2 moms the same? No. Why not? I changed my reaction based on something I know about them. Was I kind? I think so. But I wouldn't keep pestering Leslie's mom if she says, "no", she doesn't want the help. So sometimes it can be a positive thing to treat people differently based on something you know about them, but only if it's in a respectful way and for a respectful purpose.

We talk frequently about disabilities in my household and how everyone has different challenges and is “working on“ different things. We talk about how some people have more significant disabilities that make every day life more challenging and for those people we provide accommodations and support. We also talk about how some people have disabilities that you cannot see but things are challenging for them nonetheless. I talk about this type of thing frequently to normalize it and I say that we need to treat all people kindly and fairly and to make sure we are welcoming and inclusive in all of our interactions with others.

Everybody should be treated equally and with respect. We also need to recognize that different people have different experiences and different beliefs about various things. It’s important that we remember that not everyone has been treated in the same manner. As white people it is our responsibility to learn how people have been (mis)treated and to stand up for people who are not white. We have unfairly been given many advantages just because of the color of our skin. We believe that our religion teaches us so; as it says in Luke 12:48, “to whom much is given, much will be required.”
Everyone is different. We all have something to share. Respect everyone.
We treat everyone equally, regardless of how they look. We also want to treat others the way we wish to be treated.

Think about all of the kids in your classroom at school. Different kids have different strengths. Some excel in reading, some in math, some in athletics. Those are all valuable skills to have, and it's important that we recognize what each person has to contribute. Kids differ in other ways, too, such as the way they look. No one skin color or hair color or eye color is better than any other; they're just different. And those differences in how we look, what our backgrounds are, what skills we have are beautiful. It would be boring if everyone were the same.

A long time ago, people started to treat those with a darker skin color unfairly. There is still some of this even today.  If you think that you are treated unfairly, I want you to tell me so that we can see what should be done about it.

Everyone has differences; different sizes, different heights, different colors, different cultures.  For example, Papa has brown skin and speaks Spanish and English. Mami Lau has brown skin and speaks Spanish. Mama has lighter skin and speaks Spanish and English. You and your siblings have different colored skin and while you speak Spanish and English, Beu only speaks English  (although she speaks a few words of Spanish with Mami Lau) and Mane, well, Mane only says about 10 words and they are a mixture of Spanish and English. And everyone in the family has different colored eyes. Unfortunately, because of differences like these, sometimes, people have treated others who are different from themselves with unkindness.  This has caused many people to feel hurt, sad and angry. But, we are able to work to make sure people who have been hurt no longer feel sad and angry.   The wonderful thing is, that we share more in common than that which makes us different from each other.  Even though in our family there are a lot of differences, the are more things in common. We all love to eat Mami Lau's popcorn around the fire; we all love reading books; and we are a family which loves to tell stories. We like to share with each other and do a really good job of cheering someone up who may be sad. Just like we do within our family, we can work hard to ensure that everyone is included and treated fairly because we are more alike than we are different.

All people are different: we have different hair, different skin, different ways of moving our bodies. It’s OK to notice those differences, and sometimes it’s helpful to talk about those differences. Some people are treated unfairly because of how they look and that is wrong
I would say something along the lines of that being different from one another is what makes us unique, but at the end of the day we are all humans!

Everyone is special, and everyone is important. People have been very unfair toward other people for a long time, like turning them into slaves and killing them because of differences, or making people with disabilities feel left out, or just being rude because of what they believe and the color of their skin. I think that’s really silly. I like to learn all sorts of stuff from all sorts of people, because it’s cool to get to know them and learn. We have to be kind to everybody.

This country has a history of mistreating people based on how they look. Historically white men had all the power. It is important to treat everyone with kindness and respect amd recognize that some things are not fair because people of color were long mistreated. We have to do what we can to make sure the ground evens out and to speak up when we see mistreatment.

It is important to embrace our individuality and uniqueness by celebrating our culture and race, while also recognizing that our history of mis-treating others based on their non-whiteness has had lasting effects on the systems in society today. We must look at all of these systems and begin to dismantle them down to the core in order to rebuild.

I have discussed different cultures and skin colors to my son. I have had to talk to him about why people are protesting and rioting over the the past year and a half. I have always taught him that everyone deserves respect and to be treated the same. The only exception is if someone breaks the law. I’ve tried to instill values of respect and teach him if someone is mean to him to try to ignore it.

( i really do not know how to answer)  We talk about race that no matter what color skin is we are all the same - humans- She knows that African American people have been mistreated by the police because of their skin color- she is all  for Black Lives Matter-. I have not yet talked to her slavery of African people yet by Caucasion people - she is a very sensative child and emotional so I do not want to cause her more distress at 7 years old.  She is raised by me and her dad to respect all people- color- height, weigh,  if they have a disability to be kind to everyone.  ( I hope this makes sense)

Everyone is special, unique and different. It's okay to look different and act different and like different things. Sometimes people are mistreated for their differences and that is not okay. There is nothing wrong or bad about being different.  We need to respect everyone regardless..

It is important for us to remember that not everyone is treated the same. It would be nice if they were,  but we know that's not true. We love all our friends, so we want to be sure we see them. And if we see or hear someone treating one of our friends unfairly because they are Black or transgender or use a wheelchair or whatever,  it's supee important to use our voices to speak up.  You can even just say,  "hey, that's not cool, " or "why are you saying or doing that?" You're a kid, so maybe you need to get an adult to help out,  but it's super important to speak up,  too.
DIFFERENT RESPONSES FOR SIBS: I want them to be independent,  but also respectful of their elders (i.e.  we discuss how their grandfather is a good example of how people are complicated.  They don't argue with him about politics, even though we all vehemently disagree with him)

Own_Message: Some of the aspects of classroom 2 (orange) resonated with me (e.g., everyone should be treated with respect, etc.), but the bits about "we don't care about color" or "we don't pay attention to color..." those just don't seem true. Pretending that color doesn't exist negates the existence of systemic racism and unconscious bias. When things happen in our neighborhood, I have to talk to my child about it, I feel it is my responsibility as a parent to explain why people are protesting about George Floyd's murder and similar events.

We’re all human and conditioned by our experiences. Treat others how you would like to be treated. Having positive experiences with people different from you conditions us to understand and love each other more.

Every person is a human being with past, culture, ethnicity, color of skin. Skin comes in hundreds of different shades. See, I am considered white, but my skin is darker than yours. And this fact does not make you love me any less, or disrespect me. You see who I am and not what  i look like. I want you to always look at people to see them, see who they are, and not what they look like and what they wear

We teach our children that while all people are human and part of humanity there are aspects of characteristics that make individuals and families unique. We very much stress that no person or group is more deserving of respect and resources in our world. We are upfront about the issue of racism and that they are growing-up in a time that is just now expressing and communicating about white supremacy as an overlay to our existence in the US and a majority of the world. We attempt to discuss how skin color, country of origin, religion and cultural practices allow us to more deeply understand each person.
Everyone comes from different backgrounds, ethnicities, and histories and these are important to consider. We always include people regardless of how different they are from us.

Our family has lots of friends, don't we? You've probably noticed that all of your friends have different colors of skin, hair, and eyes.  People can be different in lots of ways. Some of our friends also speak different languages - fun right? - and some of our friends believe different things. You know in our family we believe that God created everyone special - He gave everyone different beautiful hair, skin, and eye colors, made them tall or short.  He gave everyone a different family background and different things they're good at.  Just like God loves everyone very much, we should love everyone we meet and celebrate the way God made them..  Sadly, not everyone knows that.  Some people are treated unfairly because of the color of their skin, or the language they speak or what they believe.  It's really important that we welcome and include everyone and celebrate everyone, and that we say something if we see anyone being treated unfairly.

The diversity of the human race is amazing. People come with all different skin colors, and in all shapes and sizes. People have their own values and cultures, languages and customs, preferences and personalities. It's important to recognize that all of these factors influence and make up who we are. Some things we will have in common with others, and some things will make us different. All of these things make people interesting! We can learn about ourselves and others by being curious, by being respectful and kind, and by being good listeners.

God made everyone in the world, and everybody is different, and everybody is special. Unfortunately, some people think they are better than others. Sometimes they treat people unfairly because they have dark skin like Shanthi, or because they're in a wheelchair like Caleb. In our country, White people treated Black people really terribly for hundreds of years. That was totally wrong and unfair, but it's how our society was set up. Things are better now, but they still aren't perfect. People with Black skin still get treated unfairly, sometimes in ways that White people don't even notice. Since we are White, we have a special responsibility to pay attention and to stand up against racism, just like you've learned to stand up against bullies at school. Fighting against racism is important because it makes the world better for everyone.

We have a unique situation where we are a transracial family and also have multiple children in our family with disabilities.  Therefore we always talk to our children in a way that celebrates each one of them as unique individuals.  We often discuss though how others may not treat them all equally based on either the color of their skin or their perceived disability.  We tell them to recognize all people as individuals and respect and value differences.

Our country has a history of unjustly treating people of color, queer, non-binary and trans people, people who immigrate to the US or are indigenous to this land, people who practice religion outside of Christianity, people who don‚Äôt have a lot of money, fat people, people with disabilities, and more. Part of our responsibility, especially as white, able-bodied people, is to fight back against these injustices and work towards making our community and our country more fair for everyone.
Treat everyone with respect.  Try to learn about the differences others have faced in their life.  Be empathetic and curious.

Some of our neighbors or friends at school have been treated badly because they look differently than we do--mostly because of the color of their skin. This has been true for a long time and sometimes it's still true today. That is sad because we shouldn't be thinking less of other people because of how they look. We should treat everyone kindly. God tells us that we are all his children and created in his image. God made us all different and special in our own way. He created so many different types of people and we are all worthy of respect and kindness. If there is someone different around you, see if you can find something special about them or ask mom and dad if you feel uncomfortable or have a question about something. We can help you figure out what is different and how we can talk to that person with respect and kindness.

It's important to always listen, be kind and compassionate. You will learn the most in life by making relationships with people who are different than you and it is our responsibility to leave the world a better place than how we inherited it.

Every person has different experiences and backgrounds. Their families have different histories. These differences among people is beautiful and diversity among people can lead to a more full experience of life since we all benefit from learning and understanding new histories and ways of thinking. People historically, and still today, can be treated differently because of the way they look or behave or live. It’s our job as humans to make sure we embrace differences among people and do whatever we can to help people reach new heights. Even if that means we step back so they can shine. Allowing people different from us to shine is a beautiful way to support them and create a more just world for all.

People come in all shapes and sizes and skin tones. Everyone deserves to be respected no matter what color they are. They are the same inside as you and I. They deserve the same opportunities and freedoms that we have.
People of color have been treated badly in the past and still are. We do not treat people differently because of the color of their skin or how much money they have.

People are all different in many different ways and it is import at to get to know others by talking to them to understand their experiences and points of view. It is ok to have a different perspective- everyone needs to try to empathize with one another. In fact, being different or having varying viewpoints can be good and can be celebrated. And it is never ok to be unkind to someone just because they are different than you in any way.
All people have different skin colors, height, shapes, sizes and looks but it doesn't mean we should treat each other differently! We are all people and should live friendly without any prejudice.

This conversation is rarely happening in the abstract- it is usually triggered by something they saw or heard.  That being said, we tend to ask questions about what they think if right and fair, why they think that, and why they think it may not be that way now.  We have talked about different groups being treated unfairly leading to some families not having the opportunities as everyone else.

We treat everyone with kindness and respect no matter what color, race, ethnicity, religion they are. And yes it is absolutely disgusting that our country and world has a history of racism and violence towards certain races, ethnicities and religions. We can do out part and knowing who everyone is and treating everyone wIth kindness.

In the past, people have sometimes been treated unfairly, even cruelly, based on things about themselves they cannot help - disabilities, gender, or the color of their skin. Although people have been working to improve this and eliminate this unfairness, this still happens today. We need to make sure we don't do this and that we stand up for people if we see this happening.
Friends are friends no matter what. Live people for who they are and how good of a friend they are not because of the way anyone looks.

Our country has a long and complicated history of causing pain to people who have darker skin. Some people are trying to do better, and some people think it is important for people with white skin to be in control. (I would ask them questions about what they think is fair and right.) In our family we think it‚Äôs very important to stand up and speak up for people who are being harmed. We have white skin, so we learn about what people with white skin have done wrong in the past, and we try to do better. We are not perfect, but we work to be brave and kind.
We should always recognize people's differences and celebrate this.  We don't want to live in a world where everyone is the same.  We should always treat everyone with respect and kindness.
DIFFERENT RESPONSES FOR SIBS: I strongly believe in all of these things, so most of these were tough.

Own_Message: I would teach we are all brothers and sisters, everyone deserves kindness and respect and to be included.
The color of someone's skin is just like eye color, something given by genetics and not because of who they are or represent in morals and behavior.

There are lots of things that make each of us different from one another: skin color, hair styles, body shapes, ways that we view certain things or have certain feelings or the beliefs that we have (among other things). Lots of people are treated unfairly because of these reasons. It's important to show kindness and respect for others who are different from us, and it's ok to look differently or believe differently.

One reason we send you to the school you go to is that they focus on some values that are important to our family. One of those values, equality, means that we want to treat every one with kindness and respect, and we want you to understand that being fair is for everyone. We want to be glad for all the things that make us who we are, and learn from our friends what makes them who they are.

People are different despite the fact that we are all people. Some may say that the color of your skin isn‚Äôt important, but the color of someone‚Äôs skin can affect how well thing go for them in life. Since you‚Äôre white, you likely won‚Äôt have to go through as much hardship as someone who doesn‚Äôt have white skin. This doesn‚Äôt mean that everything will be easy for you, but it means that you will likely have an easier time accomplishing your goals and living life. It‚Äôs important to make sure all voices have a say or a an opportunity to make up the rules of our society. Your experience is not the same as everyone else‚Äôs and this is why everyone should have the chance to get involved.

In our home, we talk about the importance of diversity and highlight positive role models of different races & ethnicities. We notice different races and model positive ways to discuss race. We emphasize no one is better because of their skin color. My children are aware of the history of oppression and racism Black people have experienced. We've talked about racist policies and how they aren't fair or just. My children attend a majority Black school, so DEI is part of their daily lives.

People whose ancestors lived in different parts of the world can look different from one another. We all have differences that make us unique. Isn‚Äôt it wonderful that we aren‚Äôt all the same? We can celebrate the ways we are similar and the ways we are different. It‚Äôs also important to make sure that people are never treated unfairly because of these differences. Get to know people before you make judgments about them. When you notice people treating other people unfairly, you should let them know what you see. You would want other people to stand up for you in the same way. Just ignoring things or hoping that it will go away on its own  actually makes things worse because it makes people think that you are OK with what is happening. I want you to have lots of different friends. It will make your life more meaningful.

People of different races have been and still are treated unfairly.  This needs to stop.  Someone's skin color doesn't tell you everything about them.  Think about how they may have been treated because of it before you judge their actions.

In many ways we are all the same, but in other ways we are different, and that's a beautiful thing. It is important that we seek to understand that the way that we view the world is not the only way and that we seek to understand other people's perspective on the world because there is great value in that diversity. It is also important that we are aware of how our society is set up to benefit people in different ways, and that we, especially as people who benefit from that, do what we can to help those who are unfairly disadvantaged and use our voices to make changes to that system.

It depends on the age of the child. If they are older, my response would include more of the harsh realities of history and present day. If younger, it would be more general about treating people fairly and including everyone because everyone has special talents and strengths to contribute to the world.
At the end of the day, we are all the same, you and the other kids in your class are there to learn.  It doesn't matter what someone wears, looks, talks, or even who is in their family.
God made all different kinds of people for his glory. Each of us are made in God‚Äôs image. We should celebrate our similarities as well as our differences.

Every person deserves to be treated fairly. For too long, our country has not done a good job of treating people fairly, especially Black people. They thought because their skin was different than ours, that meant they weren't as good a person. We know that everyone has the potential to be smart and good kind, and that the color of your skin has nothing to do with that. We need to celebrate our differences. All our different cultures have things that are unique and wonderful about them.

Everybody is different in their own way, and that's what makes the world such an interesting place -- it presents us a chance to learn about all of these differences and celebrate them. At the same time, most people want many of the same fundamental things -- food, shelter, love, respect, autonomy.
DIFFERENT RESPONSES FOR SIBS: I think kids needs to be both self-reliant and obedient -- though by obedient I don't mean mindless. They should know how to follow directions; they should also know how to think and work on their own.

Own_Message: I love that you have friends of many skin colors and many cultures. Let's learn about your friends' cultures to understand them better. Some friends have different skin colors than you have, and sometimes that affects the way they are treated. It's important to learn about your friends' experiences.

Throughout your life you will meet many people from different backgrounds, race, religion and gender. It‚Äôs important to always have curious eyes, listening ears, and a compassionate heart to include and learn from others.

What do you like about your school? . . . I like that your school has lots of different kinds of kids, and lots of kinds of families. It‚Äôs pretty cool that your classmates might have food in their lunch that‚Äôs new to you. And that they celebrate holidays that aren‚Äôt ones we celebrate. And I like that you‚Äôre curious about learning about these things that make you and your friends unique.

People in our country and our community have been treated differently for a long time depending on who they are and what they look like. Our family believes that we should help people with Black and brown skin because they have not had opportunities our family has had because of their skin color. We also work hard to change how our government works so that people can get the same opportunities no matter what they look like.
Some people are treated differently because of the color of their skin.

People have more similarities than differences even when we look different on the outside. Our insides are very similar. People were created in all different ways so that we can each contribute our own uniqueness to the world. Our differences are what make us special. No one has the exact unique characteristics that you do and it's your job to pay attention to them and contribute those qualities to the world. The world is depending on your unique abilities and perspectives.
DIFFERENT RESPONSES FOR SIBS: My kids are twins. As a psychologist Ive seen many twins have issues about being treated as 'older or younger' so we've never told them their birth order. They know biologically they're 1 min apart but we let them choose and take turns telling people who's older/younger.  I probably noted that they're both the 'oldest' on the forms.

Own_Message: It is very important that you are respectful of everyone regardless of how they look (color of skin, hair, etc) and how they are and how they think. It is ok to be different and it is is how the world is interesting. If we were all similar it is not fun. We need diffences .
All people are equal.

We are all created uniquely and look differently and it is important to treat everyone with kindness and dignity no matter their skin color, clothing they wear, the way they talk or if they act different than you because of a disability.  You can be friends with everyone and play with all kinds of people, that will make playing more fun and exciting.
We should celebrate our differences and how we are all special.  Treat everyone with kindness and respect.
Everyone is different and that is ok. It is never ok not to include someone based on how they look. You need to be respectful of everyone‚Äôs differences.

People come in all shapes, sizes, colors, and abilities. It is important that we treat everyone with respect and kindness. Differences should be celebrated and learned from rather than glossed over or ignored. Sharing food or music is a great way to get to know others.

We want everyone to feel safe and included no matter what they look like. Block people in our country has been treated differently for a long time. You might have heard different beliefs that people might have when someone looks different. It‚Äôs is everyone‚Äôs job to notice when they hear or think those things. We need to make sure that we are changing rules or ways of being together that don‚Äôt help everyone feelnpry of the group n

It is important to treat people with kindness and respect.  Everyone that you meet has something in common with you; it may not be obvious at first, but if you talk to them and get to know them you might find something in common.  And everyone you meet has lots of things about them that are different than you!  That's what makes you special.  That's what makes each of us special.  Some people are treated differently only because of the color of their skin.  That is called prejudice, thinking that you know something about someone only by looking at them, and judging them before you get to know them.  Treating people differently because of this prejudice is racism, and it is hurtful and wrong.  Even if what you are thinking seems positive (like, oh they have the same color skin as my friend and she's really smart, I bet they are really smart too) it is harmful to make judgments about people only based on what they look like.  I hope that you will get to know the people in your class and enjoy learning about how you are alike and how you are different.  And I expect you to treat all of your classmates with kindness and respect.
DIFFERENT RESPONSES FOR SIBS: I think at this age (6) it is more important for my child to be respectful of elders than independent, but as she ages I hope that shifts.  As she develops skills, knowledge, wisdom, and experience I hope she will become more independent.

Own_Message: It is ipoetnant that we respect and learn about each other‚Äôs races and cultures. We need to celebrate our differences and treat all people with respect.

We focus on treating everybody kindly and fairly. We talk about our personal unique qualities and how we are different in the family, and all loved and important and valuable and how that applies to everybody. I focus on the "golden rule" with my children a lot - "Treat others as you would want to be treated." - and talk about using that as a guide to be sure we are treating all others in the best, most respectful way possible.
God created us all differently but loves us all equally. We should show love to all of God‚Äôs creation, including people of all different races and ethnicities.

It's important to realize that some people haven't been treated fairly due to the color of their skin or because of their gender. Some people want their differences celebrated, some want their differences to not be a highlight. It's important to be sensitive to how people want to talk about diversity and understand that their feelings may differ a lot about the topic.

It is important that we include everyone and work to make sure they are comfortable in our space. We all have different skin tones, cultures, and lives which make us unique. That should be appreciated and celebrated. Additionally, we are all humans, which means that we should all be treated equally in the world. No skin color, culture, or life is worth more than another‚Äôs. In the past, it was common for people to treat some cultures and skin colors badly and believe they were superior. We know this was wrong, so now we recognize and celebrate our differences while also trying to make right for the wrong decisions of the last and fix our world to remove the unfairnesses that still exist.

My faith informs how I approach this. I would talk about how God made everyone and loves everyone dearly. Our diversity is important. God notices our differences and made each person good. Our differences go together to reflect God's full image, together. Some people have been mistreated or discriminated against because of their differences. That is not okay. We should be careful to notice the ways we participate in this and seek to care for everyone. We should advocate for those who have less power and privilege. Everyone matters.
DIFFERENT RESPONSES FOR SIBS: I think older children bear a responsibility for caring for their younger siblings. I think this is extended to everyone - we should all care for those who have less power/status
